Carla takes your hand and you walk over with her to meet this loan shark. On the way you ask her how much she owes this person. An extremely sour look grows on her face. In a downtrodden tone she tell you, "I needed a loan to get my business going. You know the drill, for stuff like rent and purchasing start up equipment and furniture."\n\nCarla pauses for a moment before excitedly continuing. "It’s not like my calculations were off, at least not in a way I could foresee. I could afford the repayments but I never accounted for the protection rackets and all the people who would want to muscle in on my operation. I ended up borrowing more to keep myself safe and mostly independent. Now I need to keep them happy because the longer this goes on the more interest I end up paying."\n\n"So you want me to try and find a way to make them happier with you," you inquire. unsure if you should be upset by this.\n\nCarla grins, sounding more herself again, "No, Celeste. <h3>Implant</h3>\nImplants come in variety of forms but the most common are cybernetic, neural, data processing and communications augmentations.\n\n''Cybernetic Implants'' - Advanced prosthetics originally developed to replace limbs and organs of soldiers wounded in combat, accident victims, and people with genetic physical disabilities. As the technology matured, some people chose to undergo voluntary organ replacement. The most extreme of them would sometimes replace over ninety percent of their original body with cybernetics to gain competitive edge on the battlefield. These people are known as cybernetic organisms, or cyborgs, for short. Some were known to end up mentally unstable due to feelings of being trapped or isolated; the technology wasn’t perfect and couldn’t fully replicate the sensation of living human tissue.\n\n''Neural Implants'' - Devices that connected into the user’s brain stem in order to interface. They ranged from the relatively simple nerve signal interceptors to advanced memory augmentations, data processors, communications and full body regulators.\n\n//Signal interceptors// are capable of blocking pain and allowing the user to exceed muscular strength constraints at the risk of skeletal, connective, and soft tissue damage. The more advanced systems fully regulate the body’s autonomous cardiopulmonary systems, improve muscle control, and release chemicals to help the body deal with shock. Data processors can also temporarily speed up reaction and brain processing times, allowing the user to experience the world in a state that make the world seem like it is moving in slow motion; some refer to this as ‘bullet time’.\n\n//Communications implants// are long range communications devices that can be accessed through a sub-vocal interface connected directly to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Audio output is linked directly to the cochlea and the calls can be switched between vocal and synthesized sub-vocal modes for covert communications and added privacy. While the synthesizer approximates the user’s voice, most communications that utilize this feature usually come through somewhat emotionless and flat.\n\n''Genetic Enhancements'' - Like the neural implants, these range from the simpler and cheaper bone density and tissue mass growth accelerators, which are comparable to anabolic steroids. If one was willing to invest more there are subtler modifications that increase muscle endurance and conditioning; mental, auditory, visual acuity; and eye-hand coordination enhancements.\n\nOne common factor with genetic modifications and implants was that the cheaper they came, the easier they were to detect. A musclebound freak or a cyborg using cheap, off-the-shelf parts was easy to spot by eye or a simple security scan. More advanced genetic augmentations, neural implants, and custom built prosthetics were harder to spot and often designed to fool any superficial scan.\n\n\n\nCeleste has body regulating neural implants and communications implants that allow her to access most local voice data networks. She also has genetic modifications to increase her overall strength, muscle endurance, energy levels, bone density, oxygen regulation, and other areas that increase her athletic performance without adding bulk.\n\nThese modifications don’t make her superhuman and are geared more towards the high aerobic and anaerobic endurance requirements of infiltration work. Celeste’s modifications means she could probably outperform most unmodified athletes in any field not involving pure muscular strength.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Evictor Mercenaries</h3>\nEvictor Mercenaries are high end clones grown in laboratories. Genetically engineered for battle, imbued unconditional loyalty, trained to be soldiers, and sold in batches to anyone who can afford them. They were designed by Xena Corporation but are 'manufactured' and owned by an independent and separate 'services' company called Evictor Corp. Xena can and does utilize their services. \n\nTrained in close quarters combat, they often used swords to take advantage of their superhuman speed and reflexes. Known for their brutality and lack of compassion, coupled with the mental image of your comrades getting sliced in half and mutilated, made them the ideal intimidation unit; most combatants turned tail and flee on sight.\n\nThe Commonwealth Hall of Justice is currently involved in a high profile investigation into Evictor Mercenary sales and their subsequent private use.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Gangs and Crime</h3>\nEvindium has a number of criminal organizations which are tolerated by the Corporations on the basis that crime, like rodents, are hard to stamp out. The key players are:\n\n''Dragon Gang'' - Kidnapping, prostitution, slavery, gambling, and drug production are their main avenues. The forced immigration of people of Asian descent to the planet to provide low pay corporate support jobs had this secondary affect. The imported families had close ties and harbored a strong criminal network. \n\nStarting out as a basic street gang, corporate access allowed them to progress at bigger crimes, their favourite being kidnapping for ransom or slavery. The Dragon Gang tends to keep a low profile but is giving the Delta Cartel a hard time in an attempt to gain supremacy.\n\n''Delta Cartel'' - The largest and oldest criminal gang on Evindium. Traditional in its outlook, they deal in protection rackets, gambling, prostitution, and local drug production. They have a record for supplying the corporation execs with contraband, including highly trained sex slaves (mainly kidnapped women). The Delta Cartel is mainly centered in the Red Light District and operates as a semi-legal organization; not that the small businesses who pay protection fees would agree. The Delta Corporation is currently trying to maintain a hold on the Red Light District with steady encroachment from the Dragon Gang.\n\n''Aruba Syndicate'' – A newcomer to the scene which gained a quick stranglehold on the import and export markets. Their smuggling of goods is something the Planetary Government would not take kindly too. The Aruba Syndicate also owns several nightclubs which it maintains as operational bases. \n\nThe smuggling portions are run as independent operations in an almost ‘sleeper cell’ fashion to maintain their cover. Whilst the Aruba Syndicate has a stranglehold on planetary smuggling, it is under heavy pressure to retain this control due to its lack of 'muscle' compared to the other leading players.\n\nThere are also a number of street gangs who have limited power but run drug dealing and other street level work. Most of the drugs flow through the above three gangs but there is some local level protection. Corporations will persecute the street gangs, seeing them as dangerous rabble, and having a Commonwealth mandate not to turn a blind eye to drug use and violent armed street gangs hasn’t helped.\n\nThe gang situation is volatile and it is only a few steps away from outright war. Part of the reason the Planetary Government has been recruiting mercenaries is to make sure the gangs are aware that there could be some ‘unfortunate’ massacres if things aren’t kept in check.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Colony World</h3>\nBefore mankind discovered jump technology, they had already successfully terraformed Mars to the point it was habitable without requiring a spacesuit. When the interstellar colonization took off with the help of jump capable ships, the same technology was applied to the newly discovered worlds.\n\nColony worlds were mainly run by large corporations under the supervision of the [[Commonwealth]]. The Commonwealth kept an eye on corporate activities and made sure they didn’t strip mine entire planets and maintained a world suitable for human population. Creating desirable, habitable worlds that attracted new colonists and businesses was highly profitable venture in itself. \n\nColony worlds were often an odd blend of high and low technology due to the cost of importing high grade materials and equipment. Often apart from the bare essentials needed to get the infrastructure going on a new world, local materials would be used for all other projects. It was not uncommon to see modern spaceports and skyscrapers contrasted against basic concrete or brick high rise apartment buildings that look like something built several centuries ago on Earth.\n\nThe first colony worlds, such as Mars are now part of the 6 core worlds which form the core of the human domain. The Commonwealth council has a tighter control of these worlds but struggles with age old problems of welfare, education and law and order. Problems which the corporate managed worlds do not find so difficult, by not really bothering.....\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Security Drone</h3>\nIt had become increasingly common for planetary governments to offer security services to visiting off worlders, especially when there were no state police present. The planetary docking fee included basic security services of a mostly advisory in nature, but also came with drone surveillance in certain parts of Evindium City. While the drones lacked any offensive capabilities, they usually were enough to scare off most of low level criminals.\n\nAdditional security services came with an extra fee and ranged from personal bodyguards to rapid response armed assault teams. Many wealthier visitors were prepared to pay the extra to avoid being kidnapped.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Back at the hangar</h3>After dumping Hugo off the journey back was completely uneventful. Once the ship landed Jane and you sit down for a chat.\n\n"We have two major problems: our ship has taken heavy damage and your face is plastered on every newscast on this planet," you tell her curtly. "We can't take the ship to any repair yard as they would report the obvious gunfire damage to the planetary authorities. This of course is separate from the fact that if what Hugo said was right we can't get you off the planet that easily either."\n\nJane nods in agreement.\n\n"Those are two big problems all right. Hugo was correct. I just ran a search on the planetary net and confirmed that I'm on the wanted list. Even if they don't have my retina scans or personal data, I reckon that a facial recognition system would pick me up in no time. If I get caught they'll have my visa details and will know you associate with me as well. Let’s face it," Jane laments with a heavy sigh, "I’m pretty screwed here at the moment. I never thought I would get trapped somewhere... Always figured it would be a missile that ended me while I was seated inside a cockpit."\n\nPlacing your hand on Jane’s knee, you say, "Data can be changed and smuggling is always an option. There are also other avenues out there like the black market. We just have to find and connect with them."\n\nJane lets out a deep breath and leans back in her chair.\n\n"I know," she starts, "but you are no hacker and I need to accept I'm going to be stuck in this area. We have little money on planet and they will be looking for us... No, looking for me. How long do you think we actually have until the ship is found?"\n\n"The good thing for us is that the corporations don't invest heavily into their investigation departments, just paramilitary security forces and some limited corporate investigations team," you say in an attempt to reassure Jane. "Everything else is privately owned and the corporation won't trust anyone else with a matter like this. Besides, once the data is off the planet there will be nothing to gain for the corporation by coming after us is except for personal revenge. Fortunately for us, revenge doesn't help their bottom line. Regardless, I think it’s about time I go call Sid and explain the situation to him. I’m sure he’ll know a way out of this."\n\n[[Go check in with Sid|Mission1.5A]]
<h3>Twenty minutes later</h3>After unbuckling from your seat, you move towards to the cockpit entrance while Hugo remained standing by the rear hatch.\n\n"No signs of any pursuers. I’m taking us down and doubling back over the great desert basin," Jane reports from the pilot’s seat. "Thank god the planet has poor radar coverage."\n\n"Yeah, corporations don’t like to spend money where there is no financial gain," you reply with a grim smile. "Though the Xena Corporation may want to reconsider their position on that after this. Jane, how serious is the damage?"\n\n"Not looking good," she says, clearly concerned. You may have noticed that we are losing cabin pressure by the second."\n\n"Yeah, I thought it felt a bit drafty in here. We are lucky that the breaches are at the aft section," you admit.\n\n"Lucky or not," Jane says, swinging around in her seat to face you, "as long as we are exposed to the atmosphere, a space jump will rupture the hull. Quit while you’re still ahead, Hugo."\n\nJane, fully aware of the situation, concentrates on flying the ship.\n\n"Not a fucking chance!" Hugo’s voice booms throughout the ship as his finger tightens on the trigger. "Give me the data core or I’ll shoot you limb by limb. The only reason you’re still breathing is that the data core doesn’t react well to bullets, especially not high-velocity, armour-piercing ones like the ones I’m packing."\n\nYou slowly raise your hands while you signal Jane. Suddenly, the ship goes into a vertical ascent, throwing both you and Hugo to the back of the ship. You wedge yourself into an alcove in preparation and hang on for dear life. Jane mashes the cargo door controls in the cockpit and Hugo, pinned down by the weight of his armour and the force of the acceleration, realizes that he’ll soon be dumped into the desert below.\n\n"You psychotic cunt. <h2>Objective Details</h2>This page holds the details for the main game objectives:\n<h3>Primary Objective - Have Planetary Security Records Wiped</h3>The Security Forces have Jane's faical scan on record. If Jane goes through any local security checkpoints she will immediately be apprehended. Erasing these records will remove that risk and allow her to move more freely.\n<h3>Primary Objective - Getting Jane away from the hangar complex</h3>Jane is in an exposed position onboard the Magnum, unable to leave. If the Magnum is found then Jane will be captured. It is highly likely that Xena Operatives will be searching for the Magnum and the hangar complexes for visiting offworlders will be an obvious leap after they finsih checking departure records. (Note: Xena will not know that Magnum is damaged at the start of the game.)\n<h3>Secondary Objective - Xena Security Records Wipe</h3>Xena will have their own record of Jane. With luck, it is only stored on this planet's database. This record could mean that Jane will be captured at a later date if you don't erase it.\n<h3>Primary Objective - Magnum Repair</h3>The Magnum is barely spaceworthy and if it did somehow manage space flight it would not be allowed through the jumpgate due to debris risks. Offplanet ships are only allowed hangar space in the Space Quarter. Someone would need to be bribed in order to use a private landing space or warehouse. \n<h3>Primary Objective - Hiding the Magnum</h3>If the Magnum is found in its damaged state it will likely be impounded or an ambush will be set up. It is imperative that the Magnum is hidden before it is found in this state. A landing zone outside the Space Quarter will need to be secured.\n<h3>Primary Objective - One dependable ally</h3>An ally is required to aid Celeste on missions; primarily used for backup and support.\n<h3>Secondary Objective - One supporter/relationship</h3>Supporters can help you out in various ways, often for free.\n<h3>Secondary Objective - Support weapons</h3>Extra weapons for your kit open up additional choices and missions. Certain death missions can be overcome by specialized equipment. \n\n<<back>>

A number of groups funded planetary exploration with the view to split ties with Earth and the rest of mankind, to start a new paradise based on religious or other ideologies. \n\nWith the support of corporate money all of these plots were put down militarily and a lot of old Earth religious movements died out. <h3>Hugo</h3>\nA muscular, black former Special Forces assault marine working for an independent contractor. He came with recommendations from [[Sid]] and was hired by Jane for this mission.\n\nJane often uses mercenaries as backup for emergencies, to guard the ship, or to man the ships guns for fire support.\n\nElite mercenaries are utilized by the right people with no questions asked. They are equipped with state of the art powered armour that makes them virtually bullet proof against small arms fire and they often have cybernetic augmentations. These enhancements makes them nigh unstoppable against conventional troops. The cost of the augmentations, equipment, and training make these ‘elite’ few rare on the battlefield as you could hire a company of soldiers for a price of a single elite mercenary.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Mercenary Work</h3>\nMercenaries were usually former Special Forces operatives with mixed pasts. Some had retired with distinguished careers while others had been kicked out for bad conduct or worse. Corporations usually hire mercenaries for missions where they could not be directly implicated, or for added security at some of their facilities.\n\nMercenary work is generally quite lucrative. Those who make it through could retire after ten to fifteen years and live the good life; using their money to get anti-aging treatments and keep themselves comfortable for the rest of their extended lives.\n\nMercenaries had to decide between investing in expensive augmentations, better armour and weapons, adding years of missions to pay them off; or to save the money and do fewer missions with a higher chance of getting killed. \n\nMercenary work was always a gamble.\n\n<<back>>
Red's Space Bar is comprised of three levels of circular rooms, each with a bar in the middle and a number of booths arranged around the edge. The booths each have interactive media screens with news and information tailored towards the spacefaring visitor. These include advice on hotels, safety, space travel restrictions, where to go for a good time, business news, and whatever other interesting news they can provide. \n\n[[Get a drink then sit down and listen to the news|Reds1.1]]\n[[Call it quits|Apartment]]

This just feels like it may be another step lower on an ever increasing journey of debasement. \n\n[[Keep walking|Int22.7]]
The location proves easy to gain access too, the problem is your paranoia eats at you. What if it is normal for your implants to communicate back to the service provider? The problem is you don’t know, all you got as a reference is that in the military you had a minor check every month, and then a full check-up as part of a 6-monthly medical. \n\nNow you have your implants as part of a deal with Sid, Sid implied that to get your ex-military implants reactivated he would have to use some black-market channels. Mainly due to licensing you were told. The more paranoid part of you says there is something not right here, you felt so empty when your implants were deactivated, but when you left the military, you noticed they were gone, but it was no big deal. Well you noticed it when you did martial arts and fitness training. The really paranoid part of you wonders if you are being controlled in some way, or is Sid spying on you? If so, Sid will know you are coming to this location?\n\nTime will tell, you think, but you decided to leave your armour and rifle behind, nor did you decide to use your stealth suit. \n\nIf Sid has anyone here, you feel reasonably prepared with your sword and pistols. \n\nThe place seems empty and you are soon close to your objective, a set of storage arrays. Hopefully holding all the data sent by your implants for outside consumption. Will it just be performance statistics or something more?\n\n[[The last few steps|Intel23.1]]\n
You head to the back office to chat with Carla and are ten minutes into the conversation when the guy she uses for security comes in looking sheepish.\n\n"Sorry, Boss," he simply says and then walks off.\n\nThree thugs who are clearly part of a local street gang enter the room as soon as he is out of the doorway. They glance over at you, seemingly deciding you're unimportant, then focus their attention back on Carla.\n\n"Look, Carla. We thought about it and figure you been tryin' it on with all this pretendin' you're too poor to pay us. We know you’ve had a steady stream of customers lately," comes the shrill voice of the member you assume is the boss of the three.\n\n"Now, if you don’t pay us up right now, we might have'ta break yer legs," chips in another from behind.\n\n"If my legs are broken, I can’t exactly work you idiots. You would’t get //any// money then, would you?" chides a slightly defiant and frustrated Carla. "You guys know I owe a lot of money to Lenny from getting this place up and running."\n\n"Well, we’ll give you the same choice we give everyone who can’t pay: you either earn us some extra cash spreadin' them legs of yours or sell us a controlling stake in the business," says the leader as he twists his gead and leers at her.\n\n"Spreading my legs or selling a stake in my business is not an option and you know it! Look, please, there is not much I can do until Lenny is paid off. I’m doing well enough that the debt is finally slowly going down," she pleads with them.\n\n"What I’m gonna do is focus on these crazy thoughts you seem to be havin' about not payin' us for right now. Your friend here is going to have an accident and it's gonna be all your fault, Carla. Mmmmmhm... All your fault when her pretty face is messed up, her legs are all broken, and then she’s left outside to get raped in a gutter til she fuckin' dies! What do you have to say about //that// now, Carla? Still can’t pay up!?" sneers the group's leader.\n\nYou know where this is going and position yourself near a spiked knuckleduster that Carla keeps for show. One of the thugs makes a move for you and you react, kick out, and reach the knuckleduster. Carla is left speechless when all three thugs go down over a very short period of time. You didn't get totally off without a scratch as you managed to get slammed into a wall. They're much worse off now that one is dead with a caved in front skull and the other two are down and out.\n\nCarla looks shocked by what happened, as does her security person as he walks in and surveys the scene and starts to turn white.\n\n"C-Carla... They will fucking kill us for sure when they learn what happened!" he accusatorily screams in a panic. \n\n"Get restraints and a vehicle. We need to dispose of the bodies," you order.\n\nHe looks at you like he is going to question you then nods in agreement. Carla wakes up to the seriousness of the situation and tells him that her car is below the building in an underground residential carpark. Her biggest concern about reaching there is that the carpark is monitored by a CCTV system. When the security person comes back, you get the two living thugs restrained and get the security person to get them to Carla’s car.\n\nYou get the details of the CCTV system from Carla and contact Jane. Your plan is to use the Magnum’s computer system to copy CCTV from different days to fool the street gang. You tell her that once the CCTV are altered and the bodies are dumped, no-one will know the thugs ended up there. Carla is shocked but asks what she can do to help.\n\n"Get on your hands and knees and clean the blood and mess up," you quickly order. Carla finds some humour in the fact you are in her dungeon and telling her what to do, but asks about the other two, are they going to die?\n\n"They will be killed at the disposal point, they are easier to move alive, and you don't want to clear more blood do you" you reply in a clinical cold hearted fashion that spooks Carla even more.\n\nAfter you help dispose of the bodies in another part of Evindium you return to the dungeon and find that no-one has come looking for the thugs yet. Carla warns you that someone is bound to have seen the thugs heading this way and suspicion will still fall on her. You tell her that it will take some time, as the street gang will think someone is trying to muscle in on their turf before they'd investigate anyone like her. You will see what you can do to help in the meantime.\n\nThis leaves Carla with lots of questions and the poor girl looks dumbfounded when you leave. You could swear there is still the same calculating look in her eye as you walk out and you have to admit you’ve always liked her devious streak.\n\n[[Return to your apartment|Apartment][$Days = $Days + 0.5]] <<set $CarlaChat to 2>>

<h3>Credits</h3>\nThe standard intergalactic currency. They were created in order to replace the old Earth currencies after the discovery of jump technology. The collapse of old financial giants triggered by the dwindling fossil fuel reserves, which were further exasperated by the ability to reach new worlds, sent the value of the dollar plummeting due to exponential inflation. Eventually most luxury purchases would run in the hundred-billions of dollars and money quickly became a less valuable commodity than the medium it was printed on.\n\nOne credit equalled roughly two-hundred fifty dollars in old earth currency when they were introduced. This means that the Magnum which cost two million credits or the equivalent of five-hundred million dollars in old currency. The difference in value had only continued to grow as man has spread out further into the cosmos. Comparing present day credit value to old currencies is virtually impossible.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Infiltrators</h3>\nOperatives trained in stealth and counter surveillance. They often utilize equipment such as a [[stealth suit]] to mask their electronic and infra-red signatures. Even when wearing a stealth suit, an infiltrator has to be highly skilled at stealth and evasion, and have high levels of mental discipline and body control, to avoid detection by security sensor systems \n\nThe high cost of stealth materials, and with the need to minimize weight and preserve one’s agility, most infiltrators carry few to no weapons and tend to forego armour entirely.\n\nMost high security facilities employ an array of lethal anti-intruder systems in combination with [[mech security]], making infiltrator work dangerous and requiring great mental strength, nerves of steel, and split-second decision making under pressure.\n\nUnsurprisingly, it is very rare to hear the phrase ‘retired operator’.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Mechanized Security</h3>\nMechs [see also ‘bots’, ‘drones’, ’rust bucket’, etc.] are the linchpin of the modern high end security.\n\nThe higher level of vigilance and lower running costs made them preferable to human security. A higher degree of versatility and mobility made them more desirable than the lower cost stationary systems, although combinations of human and stationary sensors still aren’t uncommon.\n\nThey come in a variety of solutions: Fast moving sentry bots; small, quick striking bots with specialized scanners; and the larger, more heavily armed, armoured mechs, available in both airborne and bipedal models.\n\nEquipped with a range of sonar, passive aural, optical, thermal, x-ray, chemical, seismic, and electromagnetic sensors, it is virtually impossible for anything not employing stealth technologies such as a [[stealth suit]] to avoid their detection.\n\nMost mechs are programmed with rudimentary artificial intelligence that allow basic actions such as adjusting their patrol routes and behaviour. Mechs were often programmed to use non-lethal force to try to disable and capture intruders to be taken in for questioning. Capture usually meant a slow death in the hands of interrogators if you were an infiltrator; many opted to end their own lives rather than to be captured.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Swordfighting</h3>\nIn the 21st Century, Kendo and Fencing were arts that involved either a lightweight blunt, flimsy piece of metal or the equivalent of a bamboo stick for sparring. Either of these weapons could still cause injury and armored sports equipment and rules were required to keep things safe. Neither were very close to the real art of swordsmanship and they ended up being sports where you aimed for a 'touch'.\n\nThe advancement of technology has opened up realistic sword fighting without the risk of death or disfigurement. Lightweight armored sensor suits and composite, weight accurate swords combined with computer based scoring meant that hits could be scored based on the power, accuracy and effectiveness of the cut. Gone were the days of designated target areas and scoring victory by a mere tap.\n\nEquipment was very expensive and the closest most people could get to this was virtual reality simulations. These appeared realistic, with selectable level of blood and gore, until you hit your opponent with your sword and met no resistance.\n\nOwners of the sensor suits could combine the virtual reality feed with physical fighting, superimposing a virtual model with computer calculated injuries and wounds on the opponent. Simulations could go as far as stiffening up joints in the suit, restricting the use of an arm or a leg based on the damage, or decrease the overall mobility to simulate blood loss until the suit locks up completely and the match is ended. The suits even allow electronic pain inducers to be built into make the fights feel more realistic as the anticipation of pain made for a much more realistic bouts.\n\nThe system came with a number of predefined characters but you could also easily make a scan of yourself during a practice sessions and build an accurate representation of yourself down to real time facial expressions. Some people favour the generic characters as they felt uneasy with having their own lookalike hacked in pieces.\n\nThe base software came with three distinct fighting styles built in: medieval combat, classical western fencing, and Japanese kenjutsu.\n\nGenerally, you preferred the Japanese kenjutsu. Medieval fighting was too much like a wrestling match, fencing felt like poking a pincushion, whereas kenjutsu offered decisive one hit matches. You enjoyed the other weapons, but the dynamic quick fighting style with no margin for error made the katana your favourite blade to wield. \n<<back>>

<h3>Justice</h3>\nThere are no official police forces or judicial system on Evindium for the general public to turn to.\n\nThis doesn’t mean that there is no justice and abusing your privileges means that you lose them. Getting caught stealing from a hyper market will get you banned and your store card revoked. As companies opened up to sharing data, this could mean that you would end up banned from all the larger chains and were at the mercy of black market.\n\nIt was the same with driving, as all of the vehicles required you to enter an identification card before you could operate them. Getting caught committing a road offence by the traffic surveillance and road maintenance system put you on their blacklist and prevent you from operating future vehicles.\n\nStreet violence was not tolerated in areas controlled by security forces but was largely ignored everywhere else. The wealthy simply stayed out of the dangerous areas or hired personal bodyguards when needed. The middle class paid for apartment block security or lived in suburban, gated communities.\n\nThe Commonwealth Court Service provides an adjudication service for civil disputes such as breaches of contract. The Commonwealth Justicar and Justice Forces provide guidance for standards of security services for public areas, investigates, and at times steps in if things are going badly wrong. This stops serious abuse of power by private security forces.\n\n<<back>>

"You know that [[Evictor mercenaries|Evictor Mercenaries]] were designed by Xena Corp. and probably even that they don’t manufacture them due to regulations on private and corporate militaries. If Xena wants to utilize their talents, they have to hire an Evictor mercenary company the same as anyone else. The reality is that Xena are manufacturing an army in secret. I’m sure you’ll point out that there have been investigations into Xena’s facilities before, but what would happen if they were being aided by an outside party, say, by a mining company?\n\n"Lantis Corporation hate Xena because their operations puts Lantis’s mining at risk," you quickly reply.\n\n"Ah... That //is// what the public is lead to believe," he says with a smug grin. "But tell me, Celeste: What if Lantis were creating underground facilities for Xena? After all, most of their mining is already automated and the only need for human input is in the logistics and for mechanical repairs."\n\n"Then Xena could be building an army of Evictors undetected," you say as everything starts to fall into place in your head. <h3>The Commonwealth</h3>\nAn organization that provides central government and core functions like customs and navigation services for the [[colonized worlds|colony world]]. The Commonwealth Hall of Justice sets the basic laws that Corporations and Planetary Councils must adhere to.\n\nThe Commonwealth is often dominated by corporate politics and struggles to enact its will at the planetary level. Instead, it provides more of a balancing service ensuring that no corporation is in position of complete military strength or political dominance. The Commonwealth itself has a substantial Navy and the Hall of Justice employs a paramilitary group titled the ‘Justice Force’.\n\n<<back>>
<h1>Allies & Relationships</h1><centre> <table border="1" style="width:95%"><tr> <td> <<if $Maddock >= 1>> [[Maddock]] Status: <<print $Maddock>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> <td> <<if $Lina >= 1>> [[Lina]] Status: <<print $Lina>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> </tr>\n<tr> <td> <<if $Crimelord >= 1>> [[Michael Benz|Crimelord]] Status: <<print $Crimelord>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> <td> <<if $Carla >= 1>> [[Carla]] Status: <<print $Carla>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> </tr>\n<tr> <td> <<if $Max >= 1>> [[Max's Crew|Max]] Status: <<print $Max>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> <td> <<if $Claire >= 1>> [[Claire]] Status <<print $Claire>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> </tr>\n<tr> <td> <<if $Cam is 3>> [[Camilla]] Status: <<print $Cam>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> <td><<if $SarahT >= 1>> [[Sarah]] Status <<print $SarahT>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> </tr>\n<tr> <td> <<if $Tyrone >= 1>> [[Tyrone]] Status <<print $Tyrone>> <<else>> ???? <</if>> </td> <td> NO ENTRY </td> </tr>\n</table> </centre>\n<h3>Ally Scores</h3>1 = No Trust/Forming Relationship. This means that Celeste does not trust the group or individual and the feeling is mutual. Deals can be struck though at a mutual risk.\n2 = Some Trust/Basic Working Relationship. This means that some branches have been extended between parties such as a group paying some money upfront and take a risk on the basis that you've you paid them before.\n3 = Mutual Trust/Strong Partners. This means that when your goals align both parties will honour their agreements no matter what the circumstance.\n<h3>Relationship Scores</h3>1 = Friends (with benefits?). \n2 = Solid Relationship. \n3 = Soulmates.\n\n''In game mechanics this means that to rely on a '1' score for support in missions is dangerous. A '2' score should be ok but carries with them a slight risk. A '3' is when the person or group can be trusted to really try their best under any circumstance.'' \n\n<<back>>

<h3>Metro</h3>\nA mostly over-ground, rapid transit system that covers the inhabited area of Evindium Prime. It is generally used by the poor and working class to commute and move around Evindium City.\n\nAccess to different parts of the city is mostly unlimited apart from [[visa]] control security checks at the Space Quarter, corporate, and industrial station exits.\n\nThe metro is considered the safest way to travel around the city and is policed by the [[Perco Corporation]].\n\n<<back>>
<img src=data/gangboss1.png>\n\nMichael Benz - Head of the Aruba Syndicate. A shrewd operator who runs his crime gang like a business that operates in the shadows dealing with things that are morally dubious.\n \nWhile not shy of using violence to protect its territory and expansion plans, the Aruba Syndicate is the least violent of the three main gangs on Evindium. It is also the smallest and its rivals want to erase the nuisance as soon as they have dealt with each other.\n\n<<back>>

Training starts at 20% due to Sid’s ongoing conditioning and reaches maximum efficiency at 100%.\n2. Training is not limited to 100% but going past the limit may result in a complete mental breakdown.\n3. Your training level may affect whether or not some choices become available in the game.\n\n<h3>Submissiveness</h3>\nSid’s frustration with Celeste stems from her never joining his organization and choosing to remain a freelancer. Your submission score will not increase the number of oppurtunities you have to be submissive, but may make it harder to resist certain situations.\n4. Combat Droids are the next advancement of mech security bots, the key difference is versatility and significantly more advanced combat and friend/foe analysis.\n\nEssentially a military development programme called for humans to lead squads of bipedal combat mechs, mechs that had the ability to follow instructions, understand military tactics and carry out a number of tasks without human instruction. The difference being that current mechs are programmed to carry out a limited function, e.g. patrol XYZ location, neutralise intruders via friend/foe recognition. While some friend/foe recognition was fairly advanced, it was simply the mech waiting for human assistance or other inputs to come out (such as under fire, or the intruder running away).\n\nWhat this meant was that mechs were useful for security duties and warfare such as hunter-killer and air defence. Where mechs failed were in operations where friend/foe recognition was difficult such as in counter insurgency. This started off the combat droid programme due to distrust and the cost of manufacturing genetically engineered soldiers. It was known that training human soldiers to a high level, and then embedding implants was very expensive. More so than technologies such as vat grown soldiers. \n\nThe military programme used the name ‘Droids’ to distinguish from the term ‘Mechs’ to highlight the higher artificial intelligence. The programme was controversial and while development is ongoing a number of organisations are scared of security forces being comprised of mechs, ‘clone’ troopers and now ‘droids’.\n\nYou carried out an infiltration mission on a leading developer of combat droids. It was your best payout for a job. \n\n<<back>>\n

<h3>Evindium</h3>\nEvindium Prime is a [[colony world]] under the strict control of a consortium of large corporations, including the Xena Corporation. The planet is roughly Earth sized and is mostly an arid, desert like planet undergoing its fiftieth year of terraforming. \n\nThrough the terraforming efforts it has a developed a thin but breathable atmosphere. The planet is largely uninhabited and colonists were prohibited to settle outside the Evindium City by the corporations. This was to make sure that the corporations could survey the planet for natural resources without having to worry about people setting up homes on top of such natural riches.\n\nEvindium City is a large sprawling city with around twelve million inhabitants divided into various hubs; Space Quarter, Downtown, Corporate district, and industrial areas.\n\nThe Space Quarter is centered on a space elevator linking the city to the orbiting space station. It is connected to the various landing platforms, hangars, and related facilities like warehouses and hotels, by a metro system. The Space Quarter is separated from the rest of the city by security checkpoints and all of the Evindium’s off world freight and business transactions are carried out there. The area is very high tech and contained fully indoors.\n\nCorporate areas are heavily guarded compounds containing staff’s living quarters and corporate offices and facilities. Access to the areas is restricted and monitored. Complexes inside vary from science and technology research facilities to business headquarters and planetary administration buildings. The higher level corporate workers live on site while the industrial and general office workforce make the daily commute from Downtown.\n\nDowntown is a largely unpoliced area where the quality of life can vary from the safe, gated community of high-rise buildings and shopping malls protected by private security firms all the way down to the high crime rate red lights district and slums where taking a stroll down the dark alleyways looking like a corporate person with no security will get you mugged or worse. Using the Metro is generally deemed safest due to their private security force. \n\nThe industrial areas are scattered outside the city and provide the core infrastructure of power, water, sewage treatment, building materials, and ore processing for off world commerce. Industrial areas also hold the atmospheric and water processing plants which slowly terraform Evindium.\n\nCorporations maintained control over the general populace through military power and high security border control, stopping most of the high tech weapons coming into the system. Their technological superiority allows them to operate with a smaller security force.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>The Show House</h3>\nShebo, formerly known as ‘She Bondage’, started out as a bondage themed event in a private club. This featured private shows of girls in bondage gear, chained on stage, for select members to ogle. As the event gained popularity, regular shows were put on in the main bar areas and the club began to hire key staff members to act as hostesses. Their main income came from the VIP patrons and a talented hostess could make as much as three month's average salary in a week. After event crowds became overwhelming, the club was renamed as the ‘Shebo Show House’ and was dedicated to the theme.\n\nWord spread and the club was flooded with people wanting to become hostesses. Strict tests were put in place to weed out the less dedicated of the applicants. The job had strict demands of a physical nature; one must be athletic and have good looks, along with a tolerance for pain.\n\nSurprisingly, various groups with planetary and corporate power began to favour hostesses. <h3>Visa</h3>\nIn order to be allowed to enter or leave Evindium requires a Visa. Entry visas are relatively easy to acquire with little to no background checks as long as you could afford the fee and were prepared to submit your personal identification data in the form of retina scans, fingerprints and DNA samples in exchange. Based on the circumstances of your visit you are provided with one of the three levels of Visas:\n\n\n''Level 1'' - Visas reserved for the upper level of corporate staff, their guests, or their families. This grants the owner VIP privileges on the planet.\n\n''Level 2'' - Visas for the non-essential corporate employees and support staff, trading companies doing business with corporations, key local businesses, and other parties in good favour of the main corporations. You were granted a Level 2 Visa due to your cover as a co-pilot for a courier company.\n\n''Level 3'' - Visas offered to immigrants who are prepared to move to and live on the planet as second rate citizens. As Evindium is still largely unpopulated and offers plenty of work, people are willing to give up some of their rights to make a living even if it meant that they might never be allowed to leave the planet.\n\n\nVisas are checked when you enter or exit Space Quarter. You could potentially bypass the security checks using your ship, but that means risking getting caught by the air traffic security services. \n\n<<back>>

<h3>The Magnum</h3>\nCeleste and Jane's ship that Celeste purchased two years ago. The vessel is registered under a small interstellar courier company shell corporation. Officially, Jane and Celeste are registered as a pilot and co-pilot employed by the company.\n\nThe Magnum is a commercial version of a small military utility ship. She has been fitted with a small caliber cannon, guided missiles, and a military grade navigation system. The vessel is equipped with a full range of sensors and is suited for a variety of missions.\n\nWith a spaceplane design, the Magnum is capable of manoeuvres in atmosphere. This provides a huge advantage for Celeste as a lot of the equipment she uses would never make it past the customs or security checks used in public transport. The high tech equipment and other ‘contraband’ are stored in a hidden compartment behind the extra fuel tanks.\n\nThe downside was that the ship, with all its modifications, did not come in cheap. Adding in fuel costs, maintenance, weapons permits, and the occasional bribe to local authorities when necessary, and Celeste was left with a good few years’ worth of missions before she would be able to enjoy her wealth. As it stands the ship is three-quarters of the way paid off and the rest is owned by a bank. All of this in spite of the fact the Magnum was even purchased second hand.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>Jumpgate</h3>\nThe discovery of jump technology was the catalyst that allowed humans to expand across the universe. Governments and corporations were quick to sponsor massive, jump capable colony ships.\n\nAs the colonists populated a series of beachhead worlds, the construction of a network of Jumpgates began. While jump capable ships could be afforded only by the largest corporations and planetary governments, Jumpgates opened the interstellar commerce to everyone at a reasonable price.\n\nMost of the interstellar traffic turned out to be less like the shining future portrayed in sci-fi films and more a case of hauling a big rig or flying economy in the twentieth century; only the rich could afford private ships. The general population could still afford short holidays on other planets, but most never have the opportunity to leave the planet of their birth.\n\n<<back>>

It is the basement of a disused industrial unit, no windows, concrete floors and stacks of supplies and scavenged items litter the place in an organised mess. While some of the items are clearly one step above junk there is some high tech equipment such a water recycling unit. Bedrooms are either side rooms or partitioned off areas in the main room.\n\nAccess is gained via a stairwell and there is a sturdy plant room door in between the stairwell lobby and the living area. A collection of makeshift weapons are placed near the door.\n\nLife is clearly tough for Max and his people, they can't afford rent for more decent accommodation and they take safety from being together. When advanced robotics and warfare became reality, the ethics and morality of armed conflict with fully autonomous systems was discussed in great depth, in the end the following was agreed;\n\n1.\tMechs could be used for base security, in defensive roles with basic friend or foe recognition and used in clearly recognised security areas\n2.\tAdvanced robotics could be operated under human guidance, in the same way tracking munitions is fired by a human. This was essentially no change and just an evolution of high tech precision guided weapons such as cruise missiles.\n3.\tHumans could have cybernetic enhancements to help them fight better, this was generally accepted to be after catastrophic injury as humans could interface with combat suits.\n\nWhat was declared illegal were droids with humanoid characteristics, designed to replace human combatants, those with advanced AI. \n\nHuman Cyborgs proved rare, few people wanted to augment themselves with anything too severe. Those that did often had neurological damage.\n\n<<back>>\n

<h3>Sid</h3>\n‘Sid’ is an information broker for discerning customers, which usually include the ultra-rich mega corporations and planetary governments. In addition to information, Sid provides tailored, more direct, services to his best clients. These services range from standard combat operations to reconnaissance and infiltration, even extending as far as assassinations.\n\nSid’s services don’t come cheap, but he has a reputation for being very discreet. His success rate is almost unmatched when it comes to corporate espionage, clandestine operations, and assassinations. This made him one of the most successful and sought after players in the field.\n\nCeleste was Sid’s go-to operative when it came to infiltration and data retrieval missions. Sid has been Celeste’s main income source for the past five years after she left the Special Forces. She has come to trust him as in all of the years they have worked together Sid has never let her down.\n\n<<back>>

<h3>GAME GOALS</h3>The main goal of the game is to reach one of the games multiple endings, preferably a good one for Celeste and her friends. To ideal ending would result in Jane and Celeste getting off the planet, with or without the ship, and Celeste must remain in control of her destiny. Along the way, changes will occur to Celeste's personality which can be tracked with the two [[status]] gauges ''Submissiveness'' and Sid's ''Training''. \n\nThe 'Submissiveness' gauge is the measure of control you have over yourself and to refuse those with some form of authority over you. If you reach 100 in this category, you will have little control over your actions when influenced by others. You will likely encounter a game over if you happen to encounter someone who wouldn’t look out for a mindlessly obedient Celeste. The 'Training' gauge will affect dialogue and the choices made available to you throughout the game. Changes to both these scores are unavoidable in order to achieve success in the various missions and encounters.\n\nOther bad endings can be achieved through the choices made during the game and due to the ever ticking-clock until they are discovered on planet. The more days you spend on the planet the more likely that the wrong people are going to catch up with and find you.\n\nThe apartment Sid provides you with is your hub. From there you can attend missions, act on intelligence, and explore Evindium. Missions are the core way to progress through the game’s core story. Acting on intelligence will provide you with new missions and your encounters while you explore will gain you this precious Intel. Regardless of what you choose to do, keep in mind that all actions suck up time and eventually someone will come knocking...\n\nIn order to have success, Celeste is going to need to make allies during her time on Evindium. Just who can she trust?\n\n<p class="warning">''THIS IS THE END OF THE PROLOGUE. YOU ARE NOW IN FULL CONTROL OF CELESTE'S DESTINY. GOOD LUCK!''</p>\n[[Take control of Celeste's future|Day1]]

<h2>Missions</h2>Missions are a one off chance to complete a task. It makes sense to do some missions straight away, but by holding out, exploring, and following other leads, you can sometimes change the options that are available to you. \n<p class="note">NOTE: Not all missions need to be completed to successfully finish the game.</p>\n<centre> <table border="1" style="width:95%"><thead>\n <tr>\n <th colspan="2">Missions</th>\n </tr> \n </thead><tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><<nobr>> <<if $Mis1 is "False">>\n<<print "Mission 1 Not Found">>\n<<elseif $Mis1 is "True">>\n[[Get A Job At Shebo's Show House|Mission 1]]\n<<elseif $Mis1 is "Complete">>''Shebo Show House - Now you suppose you will have to complete the course with no risk of being sniped. Of course, she may be stupid and fire her pistols towards you, but the chances of the bullets hitting you is laughable. You proceed along the course and head towards the goal, rifle in front in case she does get bold.\n\nYou are running the course and are amused to see a contestant scuttling slowly on their hands and knees across a walkway. Clearly not aware of what has happened to the huntress, her eyes almost pop out of her head when she sees you and the rifle. She says something and you can’t quite make out what was said but make out the word ‘again’. You point the rifle towards where Crimson Talon is suffering to clue them in and the contestant stares up, again looks incredulous, then a sly smile appears on their face.\n\nYou peek through the scope and quickly ascertain that she’s struggling to reach a strut but the razor wire is spinning around and her hold is precarious. It finally snaps under the strain and she plummets while a camera drone goes into free fall with her. The sadistic producers sacrifice the camera drone to record the last moments of her pain for the audience.\n\nYou reckon that will satisfy the blood thirsty spectators and wonder what to do next. Any worry about how to proceed ends when the show producers make a quick decision and sound the end of round klaxon. All contestants are instructed to make their way immediately to the starting point due to continue to the final round due to unforeseen circumstances. \n\nWith your ideal positioning, you get their first and take the rifle with you. <<if $Contestants gte 2>>Another contestant looks at you worriedly and in a moment of shared camaraderie you beckon for them to go ahead of you. It may not have been the best for their nerves as when you reach the extraction point they are sweating profusely, clearly worried you’d kill them.\n\nStopping where you were told to wait, they mutter under their breath they think you must be a hunter in disguise to boost ratings. You say nothing and ignore the comment.<<else>>Somewhat to your surprise, you realize after waiting at the rendezvous point for over fifteen minutes that you must be the only contestant left alive. You're disappointed in the senseless loss of life and look forward to being done with this sadistic show.<</if>>\n\n[[Onwards to the final hurdle|RTG4][$Hunters -= 1]]
The audience will go wild if Crimson Talon is executed by her own rifle, but simply shooting her is all too easy but shooting the razor wire holding the strut would be interesting. A couple of good shots could send the strut plummeting off and the huntress will be left dangling in extreme pain or finally succumb and fall. The first shot will certainly lead to some shock inducing vibrations from the razor wire itself.\n\nTo set the scene, you slowly take aim and watch as a number of camera drones head up towards her to make sure they have the best view. You take your first shot and hear the screams from as she dangles on for dear life. You grimace to yourself and she howls and you briefly consider just walking.\n\nIt’s then that you spot an escape option for Crimson Talon: dangling on the razor wire could allow her to get onto the roof of an adjoining building if it sinks slightly further. It would be a long jump from that height and likely break her leg but you know you would take the chance in her position. You take two more shots and the strut breaks away from the building. The weight of the strut tearing away and Crimson Talon slipping causes a domino effect as the razor wire breaks away from the other struts. The wire holding her finally tears free and she jumps at the last second to the other building and ends up out of your field of view.\n\nYou reckon that will still satisfy most of the blood thirsty spectators and wonder what to do next. Any worry about how to proceed ends when the show producers make a quick decision and sound the end of round klaxon. All remaining contestants are instructed to make their way immediately to the starting point due to continue to the final round due to unforeseen circumstances. With your ideal positioning, you get there first and take the rifle with you.\n\nOn your way to the meeting point, you briefly consider if it would have made for better ratings if she just plummeted twenty stories to her death right away. You shake your head; this show is rubbing off on you in the worst way. <<if $Contestants gte 2>>Once at the pick up point, younote that you aren't the only one to make it out with the Crimson Talon out of commission for good.<<else>>Once you make it to the pick up point, you realize you're alone. It doesn't appear you had been quick enough to finish off the Crimson Talon before she had taken out the other contestants.<</if>>\n\n[[One challenge left to go|RTG4]]
The audience will go wild if Crimson Talon is executed by her own rifle. it is an easy shot and you know it will be a quick, clean kill. The ex-soldier in you suppresses any emotion as you take aim, let the on-board computer calculate the trajectory, adjust, then squeeze the trigger.\n\nOne shot is all it takes and the remains of Crimson Talon fall out of the razor wire and plummet to the ground. You worry briefly that another contestant may find her pistols. Would they even survive the fall?\n\nAny worry about how to proceed ends when the show producers make a quick decision and sound the end of round klaxon. All contestants are instructed to make their way immediately to the starting point due to continue to the final round due to unforeseen circumstances. With your ideal positioning, you get their first and take the rifle with you. <<if $Contestants gte 2>>Once at the pick up point, younote that you aren't the only one to make it out with the Crimson Talon out of commission for good.<<else>>Once you make it to the pick up point, you realize you're alone. It doesn't appear you had been quick enough to finish off the Crimson Talon before she had taken out the other contestants.<</if>>\n\n[[You’re almost done with this mess now|RTG4][$Hunters -=1]]
In a similar fashion to your previous encounter you duck into an alleyway once you are out of sight. The man does not appear or walk past and a moment of doubt flickers into your mind. Were you being followed or is this man a professional? He may be calling for backup or armed and waiting for you to reveal yourself. You look around and consider your options.\n\nThere is a fire escape on one of the buildings which you could get up to but you aren’t sure where you would go from there. Your thoughts are interrupted when the man comes into view on the far side of the street that you were walking along. He looks directly down the alley and spots you. The man shows you his hands and beckons you over. There is no chance of an ambush now as the man has guessed what you would do and yet offered no threat. \n\nYou decide to walk closer to the man and get an idea of his intentions. You appraise the man; fit muscular build, hard looking and cold eyes. All-in-all you would guess that this man has killed in his lifetime. \n\nAs you approach the man speaks up. "I know you killed two of the gang. I looked into it and I know why so don’t bother lying to me. What I don't get is why you are here, doing this. People with your skill level are usually working for someone." This guy must be the gang enforcer, checking to see if a rival gang is working in on their turf. \n\n"I'm a free-lance offworld mercenary for hire," you reply. "I don’t work for anyone."\n\nThe man takes this in and after a few more questions he invites you to a chat with his boss. There will be no lost feelings over the death of the two street thugs, they are expendable, but he will want to know of you and your talents. You agree to meet up with him. Access to street thugs could be useful and if they are on to your life could get difficult. You wouldn’t be surprised if your apartment was located in their territory. \n\n[[Get to your destination|$DTdest]] <<set $DTR to 4>> <<set $Int11 to "True">>
